title: Introduction
body:
Learning Styles

Learners learn differently. As a Trainer, you need to understand this while preparing for the training session. This chapter will help you to cater to your learners' different learning needs and enable them to achieve their goals.

title: Fulfilling Participant Needs
body:
The participants will be arriving shortly for a training session.

What steps will you take to ensure that the basic human needs of the participants are met even before the training begins?
instruction: Select the correct options. Select Submit once you have finished.

_items.text: Set the temperature of the room to the desired level before the participants arrive.
Ensure that the lighting is ideal for presentations and note-taking.
Make sure that you only enrol limited people in the training for a smoother session.
Arrange the props in such a way that everyone can see the presenter and the presentation.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

As a Trainer, ensure that the desired temperature of the room is set before the participants arrive and the lighting is ideal for presentations and note-taking. Arrange to make the line of sight clear for the participants to be able to view the presenter.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect!

As a Trainer, ensure that the desired temperature of the room is set before the participants arrive and the lighting is ideal for presentations and note-taking. Arrange to make the line of sight clear for the participants to be able to view the presenter.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Quite Close!

As a Trainer, ensure that the desired temperature of the room is set before the participants arrive and the lighting is ideal for presentations and note-taking. Arrange to make the line of sight clear for the participants to be able to view the presenter.

title: Learning Objectives
body:
By the end of this chapter, you will be able to:
  • List the participants’ basic needs.
  • Manage the distractions that arise from not meeting their basic human needs.

title: Understanding Basic Human Needs
body: Failing a basic human need will result in a distracted group that is unable to focus on learning.
instruction: Select each arrow to view the tips to avoid such distractions.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus sign to view the content, then select the forward arrow to proceed.

_items.body:
Temperature

Whenever participants experience uncomfortable temperatures, they only remember the situation and seldom the subject or content. So, ensure that the desired temperature is set before the participants arrive.

Line of Sight

If participants can’t see you or the subject matter, they will tune out. Ensure that everyone can see or gets the opportunity to see you and what you are showing them.

Lighting

It is important to see what you are working on and showcase the finished results. Ensure that the lighting is ideal for presentations and note-taking.

Fatigue, hunger, thirst

All of these will distract the participants. Give sufficient breaks and energisers to keep the audience engaged.

Comfort breaks

This can work in two ways. It will allow participants to move around and take the necessary breaks without having to ask.

Timing

Don’t let your participants get distracted by timings. Reassure them of the time needed – from beginning to end. Avoid defining specific timings for topics working from your outline. You need to plan your time but the participants do not need to know the details.

title: Fulfilling Participant Needs
body:
The participants will be arriving shortly for a training session.

What steps will you take to ensure that the basic human needs of the participants are met even before the training begins?
instruction: Select the correct options. Select Submit once you have finished.

_items.text: Set the temperature of the room to the desired level before the participants arrive.
Ensure that the lighting is ideal for presentations and note-taking.
Make sure that you only enrol limited people in the training for a smoother session.
Arrange the props in such a way that everyone can see the presenter and the presentation.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

As a Trainer, ensure that the desired temperature of the room is set before the participants arrive and the lighting is ideal for presentations and note-taking. Arrange to make the line of sight clear for the participants to be able to view the presenter.

As a Trainer, ensure that the desired temperature of the room is set before the participants arrive and the lighting is ideal for presentations and note-taking. Arrange to make the line of sight clear for the participants to be able to view the presenter.

As a Trainer, ensure that the desired temperature of the room is set before the participants arrive and the lighting is ideal for presentations and note-taking. Arrange to make the line of sight clear for the participants to be able to view the presenter.

title: Let’s Recap
body:
Here are the key learnings from this chapter:
  • Understand your participants’ basic human needs in order to keep them engaged.
  • Address all the needs of the participants to avoid any distractions.

title: Development Opportunity
body:
Now that you have been through this chapter, here is a task for you.
Based on your experience as a learner, prepare a list of all your needs that you would like to see addressed during any training session.
Submit your task to your manager for feedback.
Select Menu to view the next chapter.

title: Introduction
body:
Icebreaker

Jumping straight into a training session may feel like you are using your time effectively. However, if you do not get the group to ‘gel’ together, they will not work well together. Thus, it is essential to break the ice.

This chapter will guide you on conducting engaging ice-breaker activities and thus developing a collaborative learning environment.

title: Break the Balloon
body: Identify the terminologies that are associated with an icebreaker. Keep a watch on the timer. You have 60 seconds to complete your task.
instruction: Break the balloon by selecting the correct terminology.(On every correct answer text turn to green)
_commonFeedback: This activity of identifying words must have grabbed your attention, as you were fully involved in it. Correct? Well, you need to set the mood properly before you begin when facilitating a training session.

title: Learning Objectives
body:
By the end of this chapter, you will be able to:
  • Manage interactive distractions.
  • Manage distractions due to challenging personalities.

displayTitle: Where Do You Fall on The Introvert-Extrovert Continuum?
title: Where Do You Fall on The Introvert-Extrovert Continuum?
body: Answer each statement True or False, choosing the one that applies to you more often than not.
instruction: Select Submit once you have finished.

_subItems.qText: I prefer one-to-one conversations to group activities.
I often prefer to express myself in writing.
I enjoy solitude.
I seem to care about wealth, fame and status less than my peers.
I dislike small talk, but I enjoy talking in depth about topics that matter to me.
People tell me that I'm a good listener.
I am not a big risk-taker.
I enjoy work that allows me to ‘dive in’ with few interruptions.
I like to celebrate birthdays with few close friends or family members.
People describe me as ‘softly spoken’ or ‘mellow’.
I prefer not to show or discuss my work with others until it's finished.
I dislike conflict.
I do my best work on my own.
I tend to think before I speak.
I feel drained after being out and about, even if I've enjoyed myself.
I often let calls go through to voicemail.
I prefer a weekend with absolutely nothing to do to one with too many things scheduled.
I don't enjoy multi-tasking.
I can concentrate easily.
In classroom situations, I prefer lectures to seminars.

title: Managing Interactive Distractions
instruction: Select the correct options. Select Submit once you have finished.
body:
Let’s consider a scenario.

A training session is under way. Ana and the participants have reassembled post-lunch to continue with the session. She can hear phones buzzing and realises that some of the participants are surreptitiously checking their phones. Ana wonders if they are paying attention to the content and whether they will take away all of the information.

What should she do in such a situation?

_items.text: Ask the participants to place their devices with her until the session concludes.
Set some ground rules to mute phones and not check them during the session.
Ignore and do her job well, as these distractions are unavoidable in this era.
Encourage the participants to be aware of the importance of mindfulness and focus.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct!

Every Trainer aims to conduct productive and efficient training sessions. Banning devices won’t work with adult participants, however, she needs to do something about it. She should declare at the start that the participants should avoid checking phones. Alternatively, she could emphasise the importance of mindfulness and incorporate some holistic focus techniques during the session.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect!

Every Trainer aims to conduct productive and efficient training sessions. Banning devices won’t work with adult participants, however, she needs to do something about it. She should declare at the start that the participants should avoid checking phones. Alternatively, she could emphasise the importance of mindfulness and incorporate some holistic focus techniques during the session.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Quite Close!

Every Trainer aims to conduct productive and efficient training sessions. Banning devices won’t work with adult participants, however, she needs to do something about it. She should declare at the start that the participants should avoid checking phones. Alternatively, she could emphasise the importance of mindfulness and incorporate some holistic focus techniques during the session.

_comment: You only need to include _buttons if you want to override the button labels that are set in course.json

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: Participants Distracting the Session – Challenging Personalities
displayTitle: Participants Distracting the Session – Challenging Personalities
body:
Challenging personalities fall into seven basic categories, though there is some overlap. Preparation through practice will help you to recognise and cope with distracting and challenging participants.

Take a look at some of these challenging personalities.
instruction: Select each arrow to view how you would approach them.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus sign to view the content, then select the forward arrow to proceed.

_items.body:
Jane is selfish and inconsiderate:
  • Get her attention.
  • Make her feel well disposed towards you.
  • Explain the problem and offer to help.

Amelia is a bully and critic:
  • Don’t react submissively, apologise or agree.
  • Don’t argue.
  • Ask an assertive question about the criticism and if she blusters, ignore her.

Vinay is a bulldozer:
  • Stand up to them but don’t argue, be angry or weak.
  • Say that you disagree with the points made.
  • If you are interrupted say so.
  • Maintain eye contact.

Lola is a hesitant perfectionist:
  • Give her a deadline and a good reason for it.
  • Attach sufficient facts and instructions to any work given.
  • Explain the 80/20 rule.

Alan is a pessimist and a victim:
  • Don’t bother to argue.
  • Don’t let him drag you down.
  • Ask for solutions and not problems.
  • Make it clear that the work will go ahead, with or without him.
  • Don’t agree, apologise or make excuses.
  • Interrupt as soon as the message is received once.
  • Paraphrase the fair criticism, be non-judgmental.

Anthony is unresponsive:
  • Start a conversation.
  • Ask open questions.
  • Remain silent for as long as possible, with friendly body language.
  • Don’t fill the silence with conversation – but do comment on it.
  • Ask why they he is silent or anxious.

Mia is aggressive, a know-it-all and a loose cannon:
  • Do your homework.
  • Listen actively.
  • Paraphrase what you hear.
  • Ask for more detail.
  • Get her on her own if possible.
  • Explain the facts/error but allow her to save face.

_textSourceContent.source:
Conclusion section

There is a reference to the following three methodologies/techniques in this section.
  • Active listening
  • Open questions
  • 80/20 rule

Check out the 'Techniques for Trainers' document in the Resources section to learn more about them.

title: Managing Personalities
body: How would you approach the following personalities in a training session?
instruction: Select the options on the left, match it with the correct options on the right. Select Submit once you have finished.

_items.question: Mia is aggressive, a know-it-all and a loose cannon
_items.answer: Explain the facts/error but allow her to save face.

_items.question: Anthony is unresponsive
_items.answer: Start a conversation. Ask open questions.

_items.question: Amelia is a bully and critic
_items.answer: Don’t react submissively, apologise or agree.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

You have matched the options correctly!

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect!

Select the ‘Correct Answer’ tab to view the correct answers.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Quite Close!

Select the ‘Correct Answer’ tab to view the correct answers.

title: Let’s Recap
body:
Here are the key learnings from this chapter:
  • Manage the training for the entire group by handling individuals who can and will distract you from your plan – either with or without intent.
  • Manage challenging personalities and explore ways to minimise their impact/disruption on others.

title: Development Opportunity
body:
Now that you have been through this chapter, here are some tasks for you.
Prepare a comprehensive checklist to address all possible interactive distractions to ensure that everything is ready for your training.
Choose any subject and list some open questions that you would pose to a learner.
Submit your tasks to your manager for evaluation and feedback.
Select Menu to view the next chapter.

title: Introduction
body:
Moods and emotions can influence the learning. Happy, contented people learn, while frustrated, sad people don’t! One powerful emotion in a group can affect the others. Therefore, it’s important to manage the emotions of the entire training group.

People are human beings, and with that comes the challenge of managing them on a personal level. It is important for you to differentiate: you should not need to FIX participants. In your role as a Trainer, you should:
  • Keep an appropriate distance and focus on your role of ‘guide’
  • Listen to the flow, but try to keep within the scope of the training

This chapter will introduce you to some basic sense-checking techniques for understanding, managing and recognising the emotional dynamics of a group.

title: What Do These Emotions Communicate?
instruction: Select the correct emotion from each drop-down list and select Submit.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

You identified the sections correctly.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect!

Please select the Correct Answer tab to view the correct answers.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Quite Close!

Please select the Correct Answer tab to view the correct answers.

title: Learning Objectives
body:
By the end of this chapter, you will be able to:

  • Explain the need to check moods and emotions.
  • Apply sense-checking techniques.

title: Understanding Moods and Emotions
body:
You will come across different personalities: some prefer to stay passive, while others are enthusiastic enough to hijack the training agenda. Whatever the mood of the group or individual, it’s important to acknowledge it or they are likely to disengage.

Here are a few points to remember while handling such situations:
  • Acknowledge concerns, talk about them and put them to one side
  • Keep an appropriate distance and act as a guide
  • Listen to the flow, but try to restrict within the scope of the training

title: Impact of Emotions
body: In a training session, different emotions will have different implications on individuals and groups.
instruction: Select each card to reveal the impact of emotions.

_items.backBody:
• Strong emotions of individuals will powerfully influence the group (e.g. happy or sad).
  • The personal emotional energy of individuals will affect the way they engage with the subject, the Trainer and other participants.
  • Intense emotion relates to focused learning.

• Negative emotions will cause the participants to disengage (e.g. sad, confused, angry).
  • Positive emotions will help synchronise the group’s learning together.
  • Happy emotion relates to enjoyment. Therefore, giving surprises during training is a great way to engage the group.

_textSourceContent.source: In psychology – happiness, joy and desire are approach emotions. This state is one of increased dopamine levels, important for interest and learning.

title: How Will You Handle this Situation?
displayTitle: How Will You Handle this Situation?
body: In your training session, the participants are enthusiastic and having a lot of discussion. They are eager to gather additional information so the first two hours of the session have been quite slow.What will you do to ensure that the participants' energy remains high and that the session is also under your control in terms of time and content coverage?
instruction: Select the correct options. Select Submit once you have finished.

_items.text: Acknowledge their concerns.
Maintain the appropriate distance and act as a guide.
Restrict the discussion within the scope of the training.
Remind them of the training agenda.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct!

To ensure that the participants' enthusiasm is high and that the session is under your control in terms of time and content coverage, you should restrict the discussion to within the scope of the training. Also, maintain an appropriate distance and act as a guide.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect!

To ensure that the participants' enthusiasm is high and that the session is under your control in terms of time and content coverage, you should restrict the discussion to within the scope of the training. Also, maintain an appropriate distance and act as a guide.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Quite Close!

To ensure that the participants' enthusiasm is high and that the session is under your control in terms of time and content coverage, you should restrict the discussion to within the scope of the training. Also, maintain an appropriate distance and act as a guide.

_comment: You only need to include _buttons if you want to override the button labels that are set in course.json

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: How to Deal with Moods and Emotions?
displayTitle: How to Deal with Moods and Emotions?
instruction: Select the arrow to read the guidelines to deal with moods and emotions.

second.body:
Guidelines to Deal with Moods and Emotions
  • Be sensitive but not afraid to address an individual if they are ‘taking over’ a session with their emotions.
  • Provide empathy without having to manage the emotion head on.
  • Don’t try to fix the participants; they are entitled to their feelings.
  • Recognise the positive and negative emotions so that the participants feel listened to.
  • Manage emotions, when required. If someone is overly excited, help them to focus, and if frustrated, find out the cause of the frustration and remove it.

title: Types of Sense-Checking Techniques
body: Some participants may find it difficult to express emotions up front in a verbal way. Using icons, images or analogies will allow them to communicate in a less personal way. The use of sense-checking techniques can be best used to deal with the emotions of such participants.
instruction: Select each icon to learn more about the three stages:
mobileInstruction: Select each icon to learn more about the three stages:

_items.title: Emotional icons
_items.body:
• Use different icons, such as the sun, clouds, thumbs, ticks, etc.
  • Limit the number of icons, for example, three good or bad or average.
  • Give the participants their own set of icons to show, when needed or asked for.

_items.title: Emotional associations
_items.body:
• Play with imagery; colours, shapes or landscapes.
  • Alternatively, focus the questions more so that the participants give a more specific response. For example, ask them to state, ‘In one word, what does the image say to you?’

_items.title: Content
_items.body:
• Localise your analogies depending on well-known analogies.
  • Alternatively, play with metaphors or use objects instead of images.

title: Sense-Checking Techniques
body:
Here are a few sense-checking techniques that you can conduct during your training session.

Select each icon to find out about the sense-checking techniques to evaluate emotions.


Emotional Icons

Emotional Associations

Analogies

title: Identify the Sense-Checking Technique
body:
Sara is conducting a training session. She wants to check the knowledge level of the group to find out who is feeling confident with the new Colour Care Line?
She uses the following options to gauge this:
  • I am fully confident and working with it
  • I am partially confident
  • I am not confident
Which sense-checking technique is Sara applying in her training?
instruction: Select the correct option. Select Submit once you have finished.

_items.text: Emotional Icons
Emotional Associations
Analogies

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct!

Sara is applying the Analogies sense-checking technique.Remember that if you plan to work in groups during the training session it is beneficial to mix high-knowledge (full glass) individuals with medium-knowledge (half glass) individuals within one group.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect!

Sara is applying the Analogies sense-checking technique.Remember that if you plan to work in groups during the training session it is beneficial to mix high-knowledge (full glass) individuals with medium-knowledge (half glass) individuals within one group.

_comment: You only need to include _buttons if you want to override the button labels that are set in course.json

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: Let’s Recap
body:
Here are the key learnings from this chapter:
  • Moods and emotions can affect the learning environment of the entire group or individuals within the group. Therefore, step back and try to understand, manage or recognise the emotions of the participants to avoid conflict, disengagement or hijacking of the training.
  • Sense-checking techniques provide an easy way to check the mood of a group. They also help to identify individual emotional energies and allow you to manage them within the group or individually.
  • The three different sense-checking techniques to evaluate emotions include:
    • Emotional icons
    • Emotional associations
    • Analogies
  • As a Trainer, you should be able to choose and apply sense checking to the appropriate situation. Also, adapt and create a sense-checking technique to best suit your workshop and learning activities, keeping it fresh for regular participants.

title: Development Opportunity
body:
Now that you have been through this chapter, here is a task for you.
Conduct the sense-checking techniques that you just read about when you conduct your training session. Film it to let your manager evaluate how well it was conducted.
Create your own sense-checking technique to evaluate emotions. Present its title, objective, explanation, preparation required, method/execution steps and method, provide examples, if required.
Submit your task to your manager for evaluation and feedback.
Select Menu to view the next chapter.

title: Assessment Instructions
body:
This assessment is intended to test your knowledge of the module, Environments.

The passing score for this assessment is 80%. You will be provided with two attempts to pass this assessment.
